See G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and is within the jurisdiction of the Massachusetts Superior Court.

See G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County, where the Premises are located and where Plaintiff was injured.

G.L. c. 260, \u00a7 2A,.proposition: Plaintiff has complied with all applicable statutes of limitation, including G.L. c. 260, § 2A, in commencing this action within three years of the date of injury.

See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 70.proposition: As such, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect him from foreseeable risks of harm.
See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 70.support_reasoning: This excerpt is a concurrence criticizing the majority’s treatment of trespassers and the continued use of status categories. It does not itself state or clearly endorse a general duty that an occupier owes a plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe and protect from foreseeable harm. While Mounsey more broadly is known for moving toward a general reasonable-care standard for lawful entrants, this particular cited portion (Kaplan, J., concurring) does not directly support the specific duty language in the proposition.
See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 70.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a "licensee" rather than an "invitee," or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that "trespassers" stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct.

See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Ma.raw_text: See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 371–72 (2010).
See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Ma.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, owners and occupiers of land are subject to the general duty to act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances, including the duty to maintain their property in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors.
See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction is being discarded in favor of the general premises liability rule that a property owner owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition. The court repeatedly frames the new rule as the same general duty owed to all lawful visitors under Massachusetts law, matching the proposition’s description of owners and occupiers being subject to a general reasonable‑person duty, including maintaining reasonably safe premises.
See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.raw_text: See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 782–83 (2007).
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reaffirms that a store owner must maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, considering the likelihood and seriousness of injury and the burden of avoiding the risk, and then adopts the mode-of-operation approach, which is framed in terms of the owner’s duty to take reasonable precautions to prevent or address foreseeable dangerous conditions. This necessarily includes using reasonable care in stocking/placement, avoiding creating dangerous conditions, inspecting for unsafe conditions, and either remedying or warning of them. The court ties liability to whether an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken additional steps to prevent the accident.
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’… Under the mode of operation approach… a store owner will be liable to a plaintiff injured as a result of a dangerous condition… only if the owner could reasonably foresee that the dangerous condition could occur… and the owner took inadequate steps to forestall resulting injuries.”

See Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc., 454.raw_text: See Bowers v. P. Wile’s, Inc., 454 Mass. 361, 366–67 (2009).
See Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc., 454.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty to protect him from harm arising from conditions that Defendant created or of which Defendant knew or reasonably should have known.
See Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc., 454.case_name: Boston Gas Co. v. Century Indemnity Co.
See Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc., 454.support_reasoning: The opinion in Boston Gas Co. v. Century Indemnity Co. addresses insurance coverage allocation for long‑tail environmental contamination under CGL policies, not premises liability or any tort duty to protect a plaintiff from harmful conditions. It contains no discussion of a defendant’s duty to protect another from harm arising from conditions the defendant created or knew/should have known about. Accordingly, it does not support the stated duty-of-care proposition and appears to be mis-cited for that point.
See Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc., 454.relevant_excerpt: We answer the certified questions as follows with respect to the policies at issue. As to the first certified question, we respond that liability should be prorated. As to the second certified question, we respond by adopting the time-on-the-risk method of prorating liability in the absence of evidence more closely approximating the actual distribution of property damage. Our answers to the first two certified questions obviate the need to answer the third certified question.

See Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 16.raw_text: See Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 169 (1980) (reasonable care standard considers foreseeability of harm).
See Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 16.proposition: A reasonably prudent store operator in Defendant’s position would have taken steps to prevent heavy items from falling on customers, including limiting stack height, using safety rails or restraints, conducting regular safety inspections, and training employees on safe stocking practices.
See Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 16.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a landlord’s duty of reasonable care to tenants’ guests on leased residential premises, not with a store operator’s duty to prevent merchandise from falling on customers or with any specific precautions like limiting stack height, using safety rails, inspections, or employee training. While the case states that landlords (like other persons) must exercise reasonable care considering likelihood and seriousness of injury and burden of avoiding the risk, it does so in the landlord-tenant context and does not address retail merchandising practices or falling merchandise hazards. Thus it is too general and contextually distinct to serve as direct authority for the detailed proposition about store operators’ obligations.
See Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 16.relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk. We think this basic principle of responsibility for landlords as for others ‘best expresses the principles of justice and reasonableness upon which our law of torts is founded’” (citations omitted).

See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 785\u201386..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a store owner is liable when its negligence in maintaining or controlling its premises is a substantial contributing cause of a customer’s injury.

See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312,.raw_text: See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320 (2002) (defining proximate cause).
See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312,.proposition: But for Defendant’s negligence, the heavy toaster-oven box would not have fallen, and Plaintiff would not have suffered a concussion, shoulder strain, and related damages.
See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312,.support_reasoning: The proposition is a simple factual but‑for causation statement about a toaster‑oven box and the plaintiff’s injuries. Kent v. Commonwealth discusses and defines proximate (legal) cause generally, but it does not involve or endorse the specific factual causal chain described in the proposition. While Kent is relevant authority on proximate cause, it does not support the particular ‘but for’ factual assertion about this defendant’s negligence and these injuries.
See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312,.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935). Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: In any event, under G.L. c. 231, § 85, any alleged negligence by Plaintiff was less than the negligence of Defendant and does not bar recovery.

See G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6D..proposition: As a further direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff incurred and will continue to incur medical expenses for diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up care reasonably related to his injuries.

See G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F (recognizing.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff lost earnings in the approximate amount of $800 due to his inability to perform his job as a delivery driver for several days.

See Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 8.raw_text: See Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871–72 (1991) (recognizing pain and suffering damages).
See Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 8.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered and will continue to suffer physical pain, mental anguish, inconvenience, and loss of enjoyment of life, including but not limited to being unable to participate in his regular weekly soccer league and other recreational activities for approximately one month, and experiencing ongoing discomfort and worry about his health.
See Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 8.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns emotional distress and habitability damages under Massachusetts Chapter 93A and warranty of habitability, not the general availability or characterization of common‑law pain and suffering damages as described in the proposition. While the court notes Gonzalez experienced emotional and some physical effects, it does so in the context of intentional infliction of emotional distress and statutory consumer protection, not to recognize a general category of pain, suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, or temporary loss of recreational activities as recoverable damages. Therefore, the case does not support the specific proposition cited.
See Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 8.relevant_excerpt: “As a consequence of this conduct, Gonzalez became frightened of Haddad, and she felt ‘angry, alone, helpless ... withdrawn ... [and] spent extended periods alone in her room, often crying.’ Gonzalez also experienced ‘various physical pains which may be reasonably attributable to the tensions and stress caused by her living conditions.’ In these circumstances… the judge was justified in concluding that Gonzalez had made out a common law case of intentional infliction of emotional distress.”

See G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85K (general pri.raw_text: See G.L. c. 231, § 85K (general principles of tort recovery);
See G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85K (general pri.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for his economic and non-economic damages resulting from Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.

see also doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Ma.raw_text: see also doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 787–88 (1975) (scope of compensatory damages).
see also doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for his economic and non-economic damages resulting from Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.
see also doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion does not lay out a generic formula for compensatory damages, but in reviewing the alleged excessiveness of the verdict it expressly identifies and approves recovery for medical-related consequences, lost earning capacity/inability to work, pain and suffering, disfigurement, future medical needs (artificial hands), and ongoing discomfort and embarrassment. In upholding the award as not excessive, the court implicitly affirms that such economic and non‑economic components are proper elements of full and fair compensation for negligence-caused injury, which aligns with the proposition, including loss of enjoyment of life as part of pain, suffering, and life impact.
see also doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Ma.relevant_excerpt: In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital where her fingers were amputated and skin grafts undertaken; her disfigurement, including scars from skin graft operations; her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment.

See Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.,.raw_text: See Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 319–20 (2002).
See Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.,.proposition: Defendant is vicariously liable for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees, managers, and agents under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
See Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.,.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
See Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.,.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that traditional respondeat superior applies to a corporate medical practice group for the negligence of its physician-employee and rejects any special requirement that the employer control the physician’s specific treatment decisions. It states that once an employer‑employee relationship is established, the employer is vicariously liable for torts committed within the scope of employment. This directly supports the proposition that the defendant can be vicariously liable for negligent acts and omissions of its employees, managers, and agents under respondeat superior.
See Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Because we conclude that traditional respondeat superior liability applies to the employer of a physician, and that to establish such liability it is not necessary that the employer have the right or ability to control the specific treatment decisions of a physician-employee, we vacate the judgment… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment… occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA.”

See Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 69.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes actionable negligence under Massachusetts common law, and Plaintiff has suffered damages cognizable under Massachusetts negligence law.
See Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 69.support_reasoning: The case does not support the proposition that the defendant’s conduct constitutes actionable negligence or that the plaintiffs have suffered damages cognizable under Massachusetts negligence law. The SJC affirms summary judgment for the defendant because plaintiffs failed to produce evidence of causation, an essential element of negligence, and therefore could not establish actionable negligence or recoverable damages from this defendant. The opinion is thus authority against, not in favor of, the claimed proposition.
See Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 69.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss.… The plaintiffs…failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them… No rational jury could find in the plaintiffs’ favor on that issue based on the proffered evidence.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B;.proposition: Award Plaintiff compensatory damages in an amount to be determined by the jury, together with statutory prejudgment and postjudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261;.proposition: Award Plaintiff costs of this action as allowed by law, including filing fees and other taxable costs pursuant to G.L. c. 261;
